title: CourseKata Chapter 4B
text:
Session goals
By the end of today, you can:

Identify a categorical response and explain why the mean is not the right summary
Use two-way tables to compare groups
Compute and interpret conditional proportions (“within each group”)
Visualize categorical responses using bar charts of proportions
Use proportions as informal probability models
Explain why sample size affects how stable proportions look

title: CourseKata Chapter 4B
text:
What changes?
If the response is categorical (e.g., Pass/Fail), we don’t model “typical values.” We model probabilities / proportions:

“What proportion passed?”
“How does that proportion change by group?”

title: CourseKata Chapter 4B
text:
Quick check (pair)
Which is the response?

Pass ~ Group

Group ~ Pass

title: CourseKata Chapter 4B
section: Start with counts (but don’t stop there)
text:
Start with counts (but don’t stop there)








Discuss: Why can counts be misleading if groups have different sizes?

title: CourseKata Chapter 4B
text:
“Within each group”
We want proportions like:

P(Pass | Control)
P(Pass | Treatment)









Interpret: Which group has a higher pass rate?

title: CourseKata Chapter 4B
text:
Bar chart of proportions
This makes “within-group proportions” visible.








Prompt: Which color is larger within each group? What does that mean?

title: CourseKata Chapter 4B
text: Practice: compare Pass rates numerically

title: CourseKata Chapter 4B
text:
One-probability model (overall rate)
A very simple model predicts the same probability for everyone:

title: CourseKata Chapter 4B
text:
Two-probability model (by group)
A better model often uses a different probability per group.








Pair prompt: Why does conditioning on Group usually improve predictions?

title: CourseKata Chapter 4B
text:
Residual idea (probability version)
We can define a simple “error”:

Observed outcome: 1 for Pass, 0 for Fail
Residual: observed − predicted probability

title: CourseKata Chapter 4B
text:
Try small samples








Discuss: Why are the proportions “jumpier” with n = 20?

title: CourseKata Chapter 4B
section: Build and test a probability model
text:
Build and test a probability model
In groups of 3–4:

Make a two-way table of Pass by Group
Compute pass rate in each group
Compute the overall pass rate
Decide: does Group seem useful for predicting Pass?
Optional: try a small subsample (n = 20) and compare stability

Team workspace








Share-out: One sentence: - “Treatment is ___ likely to pass than Control” (fill in “more/less/about the same”)

title: CourseKata Chapter 4B
text:
Key takeaways

Categorical response → model probabilities, not means
Always compare within-group proportions
Visualize with proportion bar charts
Group-based probability models often outperform one-probability models
Small samples can make proportions look unstable

title: CourseKata Chapter 4
text:
Session goals
By the end of today, you can:

Identify Response vs Explanatory Variables
Choose the Correct Plot based on the Response Type
Visualize Explained Variability
Recognize Random Sampling vs Random Assignment
Differentiate Association and Causation

title: CourseKata Chapter 4
text:
Models of Variability

Chance Model: \[GradePredict = \text{Other Stuff} (Unexplained)\]
One Explanatory: \[GradePredict = Gender + \text{Other Stuff}\]
Two Explanatory: \[GradePredict = Gender + Interest + \text{Other Stuff}\]

title: CourseKata Chapter 4
text:
Research Design
Association or Causation?

Observational Studies: Random Sampling

Unbiased Association
Other variables may also explain variation

Designed Experiments: Random Assignment

Eliminating the impact of other variables
Revealing Causation

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Session goals
By the end of today, you can:

Explain population vs. sample
Explain why random + independent sampling matters
Describe tidy data (rows/columns) and work with data frames
Recognize and handle missing data (NA) in a principled way
Create and recode variables to answer a question

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Big ideas

Population: the universe of cases we want to learn about

Sample: the cases we actually measure
Two key choices in any sampling plan:

Who counts as part of the population?
How do we select cases from that population?

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Random & independent sampling

Random: each case has an equal chance of being selected

Independent: picking one case doesn’t change the chance of picking another

Why we care:

Many statistical methods assume your sample is (approximately) random and independent.
When these assumptions fail, conclusions can be misleading.

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
section: Try it: sampling variation with a “fake population”
text:
Try it: sampling variation with a “fake population”








Now take a random sample of 10 and compare.

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text: Visual: histogram of your sample (n = 10)

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Think, Pair, Share:

What do you expect if we repeat the sampling again?










What happens if we increase the sample size?









Discuss: Which sample looks “more representative” of the population? Why?

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
The tidy-data idea
A useful default structure:

Each column is a variable

Each row is a case (observation)

Each type of case belongs in its own table

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Meet coursekata data frame: Fingers








Think:
- What are the cases?
- What are the variables?

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Selecting a few columns (CourseKata-style)








Often we only want a few rows, too:

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Filtering rows (subsetting cases)
Example: keep only Gender == "female".








Question: - How many females are in this sample?

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
section: What is missing data in R?
text:
What is missing data in R?

R uses the special value NA (“not available”) to represent missingness.


















NA is not the same as the text "NA".

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text: Identify missing values

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Two common strategies

Drop rows with missing values (sometimes OK, sometimes not)










Filter only the rows you need (more targeted)

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Activity: “missingness decisions” (group work)
In groups of 3–4:

Imagine SSLast is important to your analysis.
Decide which approach you’d use:

na.omit() on the whole data frame
targeted filter() for just SSLast
something else


Be ready to justify your choice in 1–2 sentences.

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Creating a summary variable (logical)
CourseKata example idea: “Is ring finger longer than index finger?”

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text: Creating a ratio variable

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
section: Creating an average across multiple variables
text: Creating an average across multiple variables

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
section: Recoding: turn a quantitative variable into categories
text:
Recoding: turn a quantitative variable into categories
Example: make a “HighRatio” indicator (above 1 vs not).








Now cross-tab by Gender:

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Wrap-up: what we just practiced

Sampling → variability shows up even when the population is “known”
Tidy data → rows = cases, columns = variables
Missing data → NA requires explicit handling
New variables → make your analysis easier (and your models possible)

title: CSUF Statistics using CourseKata
text:

Chapter 2 (Sections 1–7)

Chapter 3 (Sections 1-9)

title: About CSUF Statistics and CourseKata
text: Here are some details!

title: CourseKata Ch. 2.1–2.7
text:
Session goals
By the end of today you can:

explain variation and why we organize data
make and interpret frequency tables (using tally())
identify cases (rows) and variables (columns)
explain variable vs value
tell categorical from quantitative variables
distinguish measurement vs sampling

title: CourseKata Ch. 2.1–2.7
text:
Variation is the point

Two bunches:

2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2
2, 1, 3, 3, 2, 3, 1, 2, 1

We reveal patterns by sorting and counting.
We use patterns to find  unusual things  exceptions  outliers

title: CourseKata Ch. 2.1–2.7
text: Let’s sort and tally

title: CourseKata Ch. 2.1–2.7
text:
Pair prompt

x <- c(2, 1, 3, 3, 2, 3, 1, 2, 1)
print(sort(x))

[1] 1 1 1 2 2 2 3 3 3

cat('\n')
tally(x)

X
1 2 3 
3 3 3 



What pattern is easier to see after sorting?
What does the frequency table make obvious?

title: CourseKata Ch. 2.1–2.7
section: Numbers become “data” when they represent the world library(mosaic)
text:
Numbers become “data” when they represent the world library(mosaic)
Two core processes:

Measurement: turning attributes into values




Sampling: choosing which cases to measure

title: CourseKata Ch. 2.1–2.7
text:
Think–Pair–Share (2 minutes)
Pick one:

Stress and school performance
Sleep and mood
Screen time and attention

For your choice:

What is one measurement?
What is your sample?

title: CourseKata Ch. 2.1–2.7
text:
Example dataset (MindsetMatters)

Houskeepr Information before and after informing some of them that their job counts as an active-lifestyle.
What do you see?

title: CourseKata Ch. 2.1–2.7
text:
Variable vs value

Variable: the attribute/column (e.g., Age)
Value: one case’s measurement (e.g., Age = 41)
Variables and Values in a Dataset:

Measurement choices affect meaning

Units and scales (years vs months, miles vs km)

Definitions (what counts as “exercise”?)

Pick ONE scenario:

Sleep & performance

Which are categorical vs quantitative

Share-out (fast)

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.1–3.9
text:
Session goals
By the end of today, you can:

Explain what a distribution is (pattern of variation in a variable)
Build and interpret histograms
Describe a distribution using shape, center, spread, and unusual features
Compute the five-number summary and interpret quartiles
Create and interpret box plots
Identify outliers using the 1.5×IQR rule

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.1–3.9
text:
Big idea
A distribution is the pattern of variation in a variable.


We look at all values together
We summarize and visualize the pattern





























What are distribution characteristics in each case?

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.1–3.9
text:
Summary Statistics



RaceEthnic
           White African American            Asian           Latino 
              50               11               56               28 
           Other 
              12 






Index


       min Q1 median Q3 max     mean       sd   n missing
        45 67     70 76 110 72.50666 10.02764 157       0





Pair prompt (1–2 min):

What do these summary tell you, and what do they hide?

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.1–3.9
text:
What a histogram shows

















x-axis: values (bins)
y-axis: counts (or density)
reveals shape + spread quickly

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.1–3.9
text:
Bin width matters





















Which bin width best shows the overall pattern without “too much noise”?

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.1–3.9
section: A checklist for describing a distribution
text:
A checklist for describing a distribution

Shape: symmetric? skewed? unimodal/bimodal?



Center: typical value

mode, median or mean





Spread: how variable? how concentrated?

Range \((=Max - Min)\), Standard Deviation, IQR





Weird things: gaps, clusters, outliers

Outliers: far away from typical \(\equiv\) unlikely tail

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.1–3.9
section: Five numbers that tell a lot
text:
Five numbers that tell a lot

min, Q1, median, Q3, max



Population [of Countries]:


      min    Q1 median     Q3    max     mean       sd   n missing
     0.29 4.455  10.48 31.225 1304.5 44.14545 145.4893 143       0



Interpretation check:

What is the population of the largest country?
Could data be skewed?
What does Q1 mean in plain language?
What does IQR(\(=Q_3-Q_1\)) represent?

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.1–3.9
text:
Quartiles = cutpoints

Q1: about 25% of values are below
Median: about 50% below
Q3: about 75% below












“Half the countries have a population _______.”
“The population of a quarter of countries is _______.”

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.1–3.9
text:
Picturing the Five-number summary


Index Distribution









Index Distribution by Gender










Which group has the higher median Index length?

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.1–3.9
text:
The 1.5×IQR rule

Lower fence: Q1 − 1.5×IQR
Upper fence: Q3 + 1.5×IQR
Values beyond fences are flagged as outliers




 min Q1 median Q3 max
  45 67     70 76 110

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.1–3.9
text: Distribution of Categorical Data

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.1–3.9
text:
Characteristics of Categorical Distributions:

Shape: Not applicable (Location? position?)
Center: The tallest bar
Spread: How different equal bars are

title: CourseKata Chapter 3.1–3.9
text:
Variability in Categorical Distributions (Advanced):

Variability is measured different ways:

The larger the value; the more equal the bars.
Gini: \(1-\sum_{i=1}^k p_i^2 \quad \in [0, (k-1)/k]\)
Shannon Entropy: \(H=−\sum_{i=1}^k p_i \log(p_i) \quad \in [0, \log(k)]\)

title: CourseKata Chapter 4A
text:
Session goals
By the end of today, you can:

Identify response vs explanatory variables
Choose the correct visualization for a numerical response
Describe relationships using center, spread, overlap, and trend
Use typical values as informal models
Explain the role of residuals

title: CourseKata Chapter 4A
text:
Start with the response
The response variable is the outcome we want to understand or predict.
Examples: - Score ~ StudyTime
- Thumb length ~ Gender

Always identify the response first — the plot and model depend on it.

title: CourseKata Chapter 4A
text:

Which is the response?

Gender vs Score

Score vs Gender
